citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One sugar glider had a healing wound that has not been assessed by a veterinarian. A crusted scab was present on the
top of the glider’s head. The licensee informed the inspector the sugar glider was currently undergoing topical treatment,
previously discussed with their attending veterinarian (AV). Upon speaking with the attending veterinarian, the AV
confirmed they spoke with the licensee about the wound, recommending the sugar glider be seen at the animal hospital to
visually assess the wound in person. In the interim, the licensee could provide a topical treatment until seen by a
veterinarian. When the inspector updated the licensee of the AV’s correspondence, the licensee stated they did not recall
the AV requesting the sugar glider be seen for an exam, with the understanding that only a topical treatment was needed.
Injuries and diseases that are not treated as directed by a veterinarian (or detailed in the program of veterinary care) may
result in unnecessary discomfort or lead to additional veterinary care needs. To help ensure animals receive optimal care,
the facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
Correct by March 8, 2024.

The building housing the sugar gliders has accumulated debris, dust, and cobwebs throughout the shelves, flooring, and
husbandry items within the room. The shelving structures and associated wheels had debris present, with debris
hardened and caked on the wheels. One fan used for auxillary ventilation had hardened residue within the top of its
panels, comprised of debris, dust, and pieces of feed pellets, as well as buildup throughout the front of the fan. Numerous
cobwebs were present throughout the ceiling and squeegee mop stored in the room.
Routine cleaning and diligent housekeeping measures inhibits the attraction of pests, and supports essential husbandry
and sanitization standards. The premise grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals
from injury and facilitate good husbandry practices as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
Correct by March 22, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
